participants.participant: Christian Mulliez, Executive Vice-President, Administration and Finance

plist.p: Good morning. We're a little late, people still have their heads on holiday, usually very punctual. Good morning, everybody. Could we have the houselights down a little, please? We don't want the light shining in our face because this is not a show between Christian and myself, we just want to give you the first half-year results, the real heroes of this morning. So Christian, I think we are ready to roll. We are just going to have a few organizational details first. A bit more light in the room, so that you can take your notes and so that I can see them, please.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Before we start the meeting, let me give you some organizational details. As you came in, you will find the headsets for simultaneous translation, French is on one, English on two. So you may choose the channel of your preference. The Wi-Fi connection in this building means that you can have an Internet connection out of a corner near the lobby bar, the hostesses can take you there, which means that you are kindly asked to turn off your mobiles or put any cellphones on standby so as not to disturb the meeting.

At the back of the room, there are the financial tables that Mr. Mulliez and Mr. Agon will be talking about. There is also a copy of the press release of the half-year results in the financial community after closure of the stock market yesterday, that is available too. All of this meeting will be broadcast on a dedicated website, lorealfinance.com, all the presentations and a repeat of the meeting will be available as a webcast on the presentations webcast section of our website. And then as you leave this morning, we will give you a brochure with the consolidated half-yearly financial statements in English and French.
Thank you very much and enjoy your meeting.
Over to you, Christian Mulliez.
Good morning, everyone. The presentation of L'Oreal 's financial results for the first year will include information about sales profit, the cash flow and the balance sheet situation.

Let's talk about consolidated sales, as published on the 12th of July. Consolidated sales amounted to 9.670 billion, up by 6.6% at constant exchange rate. Like-for-like, sales grew by 6.3%. Structural effect had a positive impact of plus 0.3%. This corresponds mainly to the American professional product distributors, Maly's West and Marshall acquired in 2009, and C.B. Sullivan acquired in June 2010. After allowing for foreign exchange effect which was significantly positive at plus 3.6%, the trend based on reported figures came out at plus 10.2%.

Now, let us look at the figures like-for-like by brand and by division. Professional products recorded growth at 5.3%. Consumer product sales have grown by 5.6%. Luxury products, which have rebounded strongly compared with 2009, have recorded a 9.7% growth. Active cosmetics sales have grown by plus 4.7%, the cosmetics branch has achieved growth of plus 6.4%. The Body Shop has achieved positive growth at plus 0.2%, finally in dermatology, Galderma has achieved another half-year of double-digit growth at plus 14.1%.

By geographic zone now, in Western Europe, the growth rate was plus 2%. North America has recorded significant growth at around 5%, at almost 5%. The new markets have recorded 13% growth with very significant advances in Asia Pacific, at almost 13%, and Latin America at almost 20%.

We should note that in Latin America this spectacular combination of strong organic growth, with a significant revaluation of local currencies, has led to growth of more than 35% based on reported figures.

The relative weight of the new market zone increased once again in the first half and it now accounts for 35.7% of our total sales. It will probably not be long before this zone overtakes Western Europe, after having already overtaken North America a few years ago.

Currencies and exchange rates, almost all other currencies strengthened against the euro during the first half of 2010. It is worth noting that while the appreciation of the U.S. dollar remains modest at plus 0.4%, the currencies of the major emerging countries, such as Russia, Brazil and Mexico, have strengthened greatly against the euro.

It is also worth noting that the gradual reduction in the weight of the euro is continuing, 35.4% of sales in 2008, 34.2 in 2009 and 32.5% in the first half of 2010. We have already indicated that if the current exchange rates i.e. €1 equals $1.30, are extrapolated up to the end of the year, the positive impact on our sales for the full year of 2010 should come out at around plus 5.5%, which is a very strong change.

Let us now look at profit and loss account, where we will start by analyzing gross profit. Gross profit has come out at 71.3% of overall sales, compared with 70.2% in the first half of 2009, representing an improvement of 110 basis points.

Several factors have had a favorable impact. I would mention the following. The improvement in manufacturing costs, thanks in particular to productivity gains in the factories and gains on purchasing, that is stock management, resulting in a reduction in provisions for obsolete and slow-moving items, the reduction in physical distribution costs and a positive product mix effect.

Conversely, two factors have had an unfavorable impact on this item. The extra cost generated by the increase in promotional offers to customers, which is slightly higher than in the first half of 2009, and the extra cost linked to exchange rate fluctuations.

The improvement in gross margin recorded in the first half cannot be extrapolated over the rest of the year. In fact, while the weakening of the euro is favorable in absolute value terms, in euro terms this weakening of the euro will have a negative impact on the ratio of gross profit to sales.

For example, if we apply the current exchange rates that is €1 equals $1.30, if we apply this current exchange rate to the gross profit of the second half 2009, it would work out to 70% of overall sales, as compared to 70.7% based on reported figures, so it's an effect of 70 basis points for this half.

In addition, production volumes in the first half benefited from the effect of the reconstitution of our internal inventories, which had reached a very low level. In the second half of 2010, we expect that production volumes will be more in line with sell-out.

Overall, 2010 gross profit should be slightly higher than in 2009. R&D expenses have increased by almost 8%, but as a proportion of sales they have been reduced slightly from 3.3% to 3.2% of overall sales, because of their strong euro weighting.

Advertising and promotion expenses represented 30% of sales – 30.5% of sales compared to 30% in the first half of 2009. We are, therefore, close to the 2009 levels, as we indicated as of the month of February of this year.

I would remind you that advertising and promotion expenses reflect very different realities depending on the divisions, and commercial channels concerned. In the Professional Products Division, they correspond to technical training courses for hairdressers and salon merchandising. In the Consumer Products Division, we're talking about media and merchandising expenses and special events at sales outlets. In the Luxury Products Division, mainly media expenses, the cost of beauty advisors, merchandising, and samples. And lastly, at Active Cosmetics, they reflect the cost of medical visits, media expenses, and pharmacy merchandising. We will continue to apply our policy of significant investments in advertising and promotion expenses in the second half of 2010.

Selling, general and administrative expenses now. Expressed as a percentage of sales, they have been reduced sharply to 20.3% of sales compared with 21.1% in the first half of 2009, representing a fall of less than 100 basis points. Based on a constant structure and constant exchange rate, SG&A expenses were virtually stable at plus 1%, reflecting our continuing efforts to keep costs under control. All the divisions have contributed to this improvement.

It should be noted that there was a strong performance of the Luxury Products Division, thanks in particular to the synergies from the integration of Yves Saint Laurent Beauté. Efforts on SG&A expenses will continue in the second half of 2010, even though their improvement will be less spectacular. And this is particularly because of a comparison base for the second half of 2009, which already reflected substantial efforts. Overall, operating profits have set a new record for half-year, 17.3% of sales, which is an increase of 21.4% compared with the first half of 2009.

Talking now about half-year operating profitability. We have the historical series presented here, and this is merely intended to illustrate a constant feature at L'Oréal, i.e. first half profitability can never be extrapolated for the second half of the same year.

Operating profit by division and by branch now. The profitability of the Professional Products Division has increased significantly from 19.1% of sales to 21.2%. The profitability of the Consumer Products Division was virtually stable during the half year, 20.4% compared with 20.7% last year. The Luxury Products Division achieved a very sharp increase in profitability of plus 600 basis points, rising from 12 to 18% – going back to 18%, one might say. Lastly, the profitability of Active Cosmetics was almost stable at an extremely high level of 26.9%.

Non-allocated costs have once again declined from 2.7 to 2.6%. The profitability of The Body Shop, as you can see here from this table, remains highly concentrated on the second half, because of the seasonal nature of this business.

But for the first time we can see the impact on the first half – the impact on the first half of the strong reductions since last year of the fixed cost of The Body Shop. So it was 0% a few years ago, 1.9% last year, and it's improved even further. Finally, Galderma, our joint venture in dermatology, has seen its profitability reach 12.4% in the half year compared with 11.6% in the first half of 2009.

As for the profitability of the geographic zones, we do not publish them, as you know, on a half-year basis. However, I can tell you that profitability has improved in each of the three zones: Western Europe, North America, and New Markets.

Second part now of the profit and loss account, from operating profit to net profit, which is the basis for the calculation of our net earnings per share. Finance costs, on the second line, were down very substantially to 18 million, which is one-third of the cost for the first half of 2009. This sharp reduction is the result both of the – of fall in our average level of net debt and of the continuing decline in interest rates. For the whole year, we can anticipate finance costs in the region of 35, maybe €40 million. The sanofi dividends amounted to 283 million, an increase of 9%.

Income tax now. Income tax amounted to 521 million, representing a taxation rate of 27%, which is higher than the rate of the first half of 2009, which was 23.3%. This increase is mainly because allowance has been made for the likely impact of tax audits in progress, and this is also the result of the increase in withholding tax on intra-group dividends. For the full year, we may anticipate a taxation rate in the region of 29%. Net profit, excluding non-recurrent items, amounts to 1.411 billion, which is an increase of 16% – 16.5%. Finally, net earnings per share amounted to 2.39, up by 15.3.

Last part of the profit and loss account, after allowing for non-recurrent items, that is a charge of €97 million net of tax, net profit amounted to €1.314 billion, up by 21%. The non-recurrent items consist firstly of restructuring costs amounting to 12 million net and secondly of provisions for liabilities arising from investigations by competition control authorities and intangible asset impairments.

Cash flow statement. Gross cash flow amounted to €1.792 billion, an increase of 15.4%. Changes – increases in working capital was €289 million. The changes in the working capital item have present by far more than it will increase over the full year as is usually the case. This happened this year at the end of June.

Over the full year, we may expect an increase in changes in working capital of slightly over €100 million. It should be noted that the trade accounts receivable item naturally increases and this is a good thing as business picks up even though the teams concern or the dedicated teams remained extremely vigilant in controlling this item. Investments have remained well under control at 3.3% of overall sales. For the full year, we can expect investments in the region of 4% of sales. Finally, after a dividend payment and after the buying of stakes, let me remind you of the acquisition of C. B. Sullivan and the distributor of professional products in the USA and of the nail varnish brand Essie, the remaining cash flow amounts to €200 million.

Talking about the balance sheet, again the balance sheet is extremely robust. Shareholders' equity represents some 58% of total assets. The increase of total assets compared with 2009 is the result of the balance between the following: The positive factor profit for the period and cumulative translation adjustments and a negative factor corresponds to the payment of dividends under valuation of the Sanofi-aventis shares.

Finally, let's talk about the gearing ratio; lastly, net debt came out at 1.673 billion down by almost €300 million compared with the end of 2009. Gearing, i.e. the debt equity ratio came out at 11.7%. And it may be estimated that the net financial debt at December 31, 2010 could be less than €1 billion.
Thank you for your attention.

Thank you, Christian. Now, as you have seen the results for the first half of this year are extremely positive from every point of view, once again the world cosmetics market is growing and we have returned to strong organic growth with market share gains across all continents, development and reinforcement of our major global brands, together with a strong increase in our results both in value and quality terms.

Now firstly, the cosmetics market, this has picked up very well, which is good news, despite the economic environment remaining uncertain in the first half, the worldwide market for cosmetics products has indeed returned to growth with an increase that we estimate to be – and it really is an estimate and nothing more, but we've estimate it to be around 4%, as we had forecast.

Western Europe, the market was just positive, plus 0.2% which is actually not that bad in view of this serious economic turbulence which has affected the continent over the first six months. Now, some countries even achieved significantly positive growth rates such as United Kingdom and northern countries. The market trend was positive in North America where we estimate growth of 2%, even though there has not really been any evidence of genuine economic upturn there for the moment.

Trending in Japan is negative, but the big news once again was the strong revival in cosmetics markets growth in the new countries or new markets, coming at 9.5% with the rates of 10.8% in Asia Pacific, excluding Japan of course, 12.7% in Latin America, 5.8% in Africa Middle East and 5.1 in Eastern Europe. I stress these estimates are probably fairly accurate once.

The acceleration of cosmetics consumption in the new countries confirms the remarkable appetite of the new middle classes for beauty products. And the resulting historic sea change, I will call it in the worldwide cosmetics' market that I've often referred to. That in the first half of 2010 the new countries accounted for 53% of the world market. And 87% of the organic growth on this market, which is of course almost all that.

On the full year 2010, we believe that the growth rate of the worldwide cosmetics market should stay around its level of around 4%, meaning that the beauty products market we operate on is confirming its strength and its tonnage. It's strong because I say because remember the market trend remained positive in 2009, despite the harshness of the economic crisis and it shows that our consumers in all the developed countries touch great importance to cosmetic or beauty products. And I insist dynamic, because you can see it started growing strongly ones again right from the start of 2010 driven by the powerful appetites of consumers in these new markets.

Now L'Oreal returned to organic growth in the first half, pulling out our major strategic choices because the Group returned to strong growth in the first half of 2.2%. Thanks to the combined impact of the clear return to organic growth of 6.3%, a positive exchange rate effects which makes pleasant change of 3.6%.

I would emphasis that this organic growth has been achieved as of the all four divisions which have all returned to good level of growth, particularly in the luxury products division, which was the one that was hit mostly in 2009.

And there's been growth in three geographic zones with of course very strong growths in the new markets, which in a near future also become the Group's largest business zone, and now up 13%. And I was saying actually that in August this is really historic, I think, first for L'Oreal, the new markets zone on this particular month will come top in terms of L'Oreal figures, which I think is dates that will mark the group.

Also we've had good return to growth in North America were as about 4.9%. And this is in particular thanks to market share gains in the consumer division. And actually the 2% growth performance in Western Europe was quite good as well. And it has been – actually this is growth across the road in all categories, because as you can see from the screen, we are growing everywhere, but particularly in skin care, make-up and fragrances. Fragrances being a business that was badly hit last year. So this return to organic growth is because of the results of our major strategic choices of the last couple of year, I'll remind you what they were.

Firstly focus on major global innovations with higher value added, but at accessible prices, such as Inneov. That we've talked all lot about, it's true. But it really is the biggest professional hair color success story of all time. It is now found its way to 60,000 hairs salons. And it's almost all in Europe, so there is a huge amount of headroom now.

And this launch means that we have been able to win a record number of new salons and you know that in professionals we win markets hair salon by hair salons. So it really is about getting to turn the door, so that you can continue to rollout success in salons one by one. We've now achieved figure of 10,000 which is a record high, but it's also meant that we've been able to stimulate color service consumption in salons.

In consumer we have products such as Youth Code, Matte Morphose, the biggest mascara success in Maybelline history I think or has a Total Repair 5 for L'Oreal. So these are major global blockbusters, driving our growth in skincare, make-up and hair care.

In the luxury products division. Genifique and I went to, we need to talk about Genifique because it's continuing its global success. We'll talk about growth of not just one year, but maybe three, five and ten years as Genifique is continuing its global penetration, thanks to spectacular successes, which also are fully deserved in view of the product's remarkable quality.

So the Hypnose Precious Cells, the first truly regenerative mascara by Lancôme and magnificently represented by Julia Roberts. And there is Rege lift volumetry revolution in anti-aging skincare, also represented by first model Kate Winslet. And then also successes in fragrances such as Parisienne and the re-launch of Opium at Yves Saint Laurent.

In active cosmetics we have Redermic [+] by La Roche Posay, the first anti-aging skincare lines specifically designed for sensitive skin. And LiftActiv CxP Total by Vichy and finally, at the Body Shop, Nutriganics, the first complete range of certified organic skincare products.

And we are going to continue because you have to remember that these innovations are really the growth drivers, what's going to enable us to win market shares, motivations around the world. We are going to continue and expand even this policy of major innovations with high value-added and accessible prices in the second half with spectacular and innovative major launches such as Luxury, Teint Miracle by Lancôme, once again a revolutionary technology which creates the aura of sublime skin. So it really is a revolution in foundation.

Rouge Pur Couture by Yves Saint Laurent to mark the comeback – the spectacular major comeback of Yves Saint Laurent into lipsticks and 3 major new fragrances. So firstly we have Belle d'Opium by Yves Saint Laurent which is going to be a new generation Opium for the young girls, the daughters of those who bought Opium 30 years ago.

Acqua Di Gio by Giorgio Armani, the seductive appeal and freshness of Giorgio Armani, which has made Acqua Di Gio the world's number one male fragrance, which is now available in a version for women. And there has been a spectacular takeoff in all countries by the product.

And outstanding success by Big Pony Collection of Ralph Lauren, all the modernity of Givenchy and elegance of Ralph Lauren in the collection of 4 scents designed to conquer men's markets around the world. And our launches, the two launches, just had Acqua Di Gio and Big Pony, have been spectacular successes.

Still in consumer, for example, we have Elsève collagen and the new Fructis by Garnier. Hydraphase Intense by La Roche-Posay and a very substantial cluster of products from The Body Shop with Natrulift, DeoDry and Rainforest.

So major innovations. Now second major strategic choice which is very important is powerful and successful breakthroughs in new key categories, the aim being to generate new growth. So firstly on men's market.

The powerful expansion of the L'Oréal Men Expert brand with 30% growth in first half and which this year should achieved global sales of around €250 million. So this is now beginning to be important. We've always said that the men's market is one that has huge future potential. We are now getting there and we think that with Men Expert we're going to have the first men's care brand in the world and it will be generating serious sales. But the key area there is Asia where men consumers, a large amount of skincare products, and in fact, China is now number one in that market.

There's also been breakthrough in the deodorants markets with the outstanding success of Garnier Mineral, which was originally launched in Latin America in 2008 and then in Eastern Europe in 2009; and earlier in this year in Western Europe. And it has achieved very success – satisfactory success. And all this means that we now have a foothold on this very important market, perfectly complements our existing market.

Our third major strategic choice of this last year is the acceleration – geographic expansion in the global markets. We've had important and successful breakthroughs in many countries which are crucial for the future, starting with China, of course, which in this first half of the 2010 has become L'Oréal's number 3 country and it will remain over the rest of the year. This is historic milestone now, third after France and the U.S.
Our growth rate in China was 14%. We are the leader in almost all of our business apart from shampoos and are particularly well placed to take advantage of the huge potential of Chinese market.

Then another interesting market is Brazil, which really is confirming its position as one of the major new markets for cosmetics. The developments there have been really spectacular. We've had huge growth 24% in the first half, then it's Russia up 17%. Russia we are number 1 by very long way, very strong market position, and in fact in September we will be opening our new plant at Kaluga which can cope with the fast growth in units sales.

India, we're up 32% with this particular success, as you all know, of the Garnier brand, but also the very rapid rollout of Matrix in hair salons where we have now won over 11,000 hair salons. And of course it's not just about the BRIC countries, but there are others that are very important when it comes to winning global markets, crucial for our future. Mexico, for example, up 11%, South Korea up 21%, Argentina up 38%, Ukraine up 28%, Indonesia up 25% and Philippines up 26%, to name just a few.

And finally to the fourth major strategic choice in this first half, the increase in R&D spend and in business drivers to underpin and accelerate our organic growth. As Christian showed in R&D, we have spent, although you can't really see it in the statements, because most of our expenditure is in euros and therefore it is not visible. But on a like-with-like basis compared against growth, it's very significant and it's our strategic aim to increase resources available for research with 2 aims in mind.
First objective, obviously being to continue to innovate so that we can really come up with breakthrough formulas in major categories, has been the case in and the various areas there.

But the second objective is what we call universalization. This means the development on each continent formulations, specifically adapted to the specific needs of local consumers, for example, the formulation of – by L'Oréal hair products in China that we tested on 40,000 consumers to find the perfect formulation for Chinese hair, which is very different from Caucasian hair.

We in this quarter have also significantly boosted our advertising promotion spend by 12%. That's an increase of 50 basis points, and as Christian pointed out, you have to realize that these investments cover a wide range of different business drivers depending on the division, businesses and channels. And here we have 2 objectives too to continue increasing these drivers, which as I am sure you understand are crucially important in building the success and leadership of our brands on all markets around the world. At the same time, and there's no contradiction here, we have to constantly rethink, renegotiate, re-engineer these investments so as to continue optimize cost and productivity. And we think that in this way in 2010 we should reach a level of spend investment, which will be comparable with that of 2009.

So these strategic investments underpin the world development of our major brands, which are now again recording strong growth, sometimes double digit growth, such as Maybelline, the world leader in mass-market make-up, which has been rolled out worldwide. And Lancôme, world's number 1 in luxury segment, is undergoing a major renewal, Yves Saint Laurent that we are delighted to see us enjoying genuine renaissance, La Roche-Posay, which is preferred brand of dermatologists around the world, once again enjoying global growth. Matrix, the accessible brand of hairdressers all over the world, and the growth champion, Kiehl's, which in the first 6 months grew by 51%.

So overall thanks to the strengths of our brands, the quality of our innovations, the power of our business drivers and the talent of all hugely motivated teams we are winning market share and we are strengthening our positions in all geographic zones.
So this first half is borne out, our strategic choices, our determination to concentrate on limited number of major brands and key initiatives to ensure the strategy is perfectly implemented.

Results now, see our financials have improved strongly both in value and quality terms. The decisions we have taken, the efforts we have made over the last 2 years have led in first half to return to a record level of operating profit, even though of course, we're well aware this figure won't be extrapolated to the full year.

In gross profit terms, I'd say that all the actions taken in terms of centralization and strategization of purchasing, together with the progress made in industrial productivity and supply chain modernization, optimization have enabled a very substantial improvement to be achieved in this first half, 110 basis points. Meanwhile, strict control of our cost restructuring carried out, generated a sharp reduction of SGA costs, 100 basis points. All this management efforts have enabled the financing of the increase of business drivers or 50 basis points and a very substantial improvement of operating by about 160 basis points, taking it back to its all time high of which was the level just before the crisis hit, first half of 2008.

Financial terms, cash flow has remained excellent, with record first half operating cash flow of €1.182 billion, which has enabled us to reduce financial debt which has also reached a historically low level, 11.7% of shareholder equity. And our balance sheet has been now strengthened.

So in conclusion, the first half results showed that L'Oréal is emerging from the crisis and as we had announced, transformed and strengthened and it's ready to score new victories, we have return to organic growth. We are conquering global markets at a faster pace and a virtuous circle of performance, this very L'Oréal idea, virtuous circle of performance is now forming so we approach the second half with confidence even though the – we have to be aware the economic environment is still very uncertain.

Finally, this return to growth in the first half also confirms our confidence about outstanding development prospects and our aim of winning 1 billion new consumers across the world over the next 10 years. Well, I can tell you that all our employees are fully focused on achieving this target, which is the key objective of our company for the coming years here at L'Oréal. Thank you.
[Foreign language]. We move on to the Q&A session. We need a bit more light in this room please, so that we can see your faces.
[Foreign Language].
Is Celine going to get the ball rolling? That is a want. Yes, go ahead Celine. Very, very dim indeed, switch on the wrong switch, okay. We need more light in this room. Go ahead Celine.

Yes, I have a question. When you talk about the market, you said that there was a growth of 4% and you are expecting growth of 4% in the second half. Wasn't there a positive impact in the first half because of the fact that the first half of 2009 had been very tough. Aren't we being a little bit too optimistic if we look at what's happened in Western Europe over the last quarters? I mean, that's the first question, aren't we being too optimistic?

Well, first question first. You are not completely mistaken. There's a very slight impact. We are – been reconstituting our stocks, not restocking so much, because I think that's all distributors and retailers worldwide underwent some problems during the crisis and they now want to reconstitute their stocks which went down during the recession. But there are some pockets where there were some cases of stock reconstitution. But this is a very small impact indeed. We would like to get out of this discussion which is endless. Over the long-term, the effect is smoothed out. So it's true that the market was between 3 and 4. It's very difficult to actually tell you where the difference comes from.

Now, regarding the second half of the year, we can't really know what the growth rate will be. We are 8 months into the year. We can see that what has happened in the markets in July and August – we can see that what has happened in July has confirmed the previous trends. In fact, the trend has not improved, but has not deteriorated in an alarming fashion. So, to be more cautious, we should say that there will be a growth rate between 3 and 4. That was our announcement. We haven't really made a mistake, because that's what we had announced last year.

A lot of people thought that the market would collapse. We felt that it would remain positive and it remained positive. At the beginning of the year, we said between 3and 4. We consider that it will still be between 3 and 4. So we are fairly confident that the market will be fairing fairly well.

There's a good reason to this. Experience has shown two things. Number one as I said, we can see that in mature markets, cosmetics consumption has been holding up pretty well. Consumers are not ready to give up on the use of cosmetics, even though the business cycle or the economic situation is becoming tougher, they have shown this in 2009, if it were to become a bit tougher, I think that the same trend would apply.

And we can see that there is a great deal of appetite for cosmetics elsewhere in the world and this is a trend that won't be stopped, and there are hundreds of millions of customers in the world, in China, in Indonesia, in the Philippines or in Brazil, who really have this natural appetite for beauty products, for cosmetics. For them it is an important product that contributes to their quality – the quality of their actual life. So it's not a volatile product.

We are talking about a very strong sturdy market. Cosmetics market is developing for fundamental essential reasons and it will continue to develop. Obviously, there might be little highs and lows and hitches from half to half or from quarter to quarter, but that's not fundamentally significant. What was your second question?

I have a second question, and then I have a third question for Christian Mulliez. But I will go quickly. The first question on the SG&A costs, we have seen a drop of 100 basis points as you've indicated. Now, was it the positive impact of the restructuring announced over the last 18 months or is there a recurrent effect or impact and on the middle-term, would it be 90%, 70%, 20% of overall sales, what exactly would be the impact mid-term? Now, focusing on the third question, we have debt levels, the net debt levels are very low. Can we consider a share buyback possibility in the short-term, would that be an option?
Christian you start.

Yes, it's true that the debt level has been decreased. We could have net debt level of zero at the end of 2011, that's a definite possibility. You know that our policy is target acquisitions. That's what we want to do. For the time being we have no project to engage in share buyback programs.

Now regarding the SG&A, here again I'd like to say that there is a two-fold effect or impact. First of all, we had the restructuring that has being going on which has had an impact but the main impact comes from all the measures that we've undertaken to control our costs.

Now, we have decided that L'Oreal should be able to develop internally. Organic growth should be a positive. So what we want to do, of course, is to keep a cap on our costs and control our costs. So we've been working on larger, better organization, more optimization, keeping down our staffing levels, reducing our costs, travel costs and others. All of this will enable us to keep our costs well under control, and there will be a positive trend in the cost-sales ratio. We certainly hope that we will experience regular improvement in this item over the next two years.
This lady, please. I think this lady first and then you, ma'am.

I am interested to get a little bit more information about the development of the consumer products division, and in particular about the profitability development. Given the huge progress that you have made all over the allover business, it would be really interesting to see what has held back further margin progress on the consumer products division? And obviously these are first half results, so it would be very interesting to hear your view on how that is going to develop for the full year? Thank you.

Okay. That's a good question. In fact, it's true that you've seen a little dip on the profitability of the consumer division in the first half. It is mostly due or 100% due to the one-time cost of the launch of the deodorants. You know that we have launched a very strong initiative at the beginning of the year in all countries of Western Europe on deodorants. And this has a cost.

I remember when I launched Fructis in the U.S. six or seven years ago, I mean the first year is definitely an investment because you have to pay for getting in the stores. United States. and very confident and I'm sure this is a market where we'll make money in the future. It's a very important, very significant market, where technology is increasingly key, and therefore, our R&D people can provide high value-added innovations at accessible prices. Next question.

You talked about men's product in the cosmetics market, that it was a very significant market segment. You said mass-market products should be given priority compared to luxury products, and in Kiehl's, Biotherm or Lancôme you have quite a lot of men's products. That's a very relevant question indeed. First of all, for the last 25 years or so we've been trying to launch men's products so – and I was disappointed for the last 25 years because every time there were initiatives they were relatively few men buying these products and this was mainly because we were really trying to sell to western men or European men who don't really respond to these kind of initiatives. And the real breakthrough in the male market came from Asia, because Asian men, the Chinese in particular but also Thai men, Indonesian men, Indian men and so on have no taboo in that respect, quite the reverse. They think that they should be taking care of themselves, that it's a normal thing, it's the same as wearing nice clothes and so on. So that's something that's absolutely normal, that is something that happens daily and it's part of their daily routine.

And that's why we have been speeding up the launches of our male products, and it comes from our Asian experiment, Men Expert became the leading men's brand in China despite the fact that there is harsh competition in that area. We are really in the process of winning the battle and we are going to conquer the world from – starting from Asia.

You were talking about Garnier, there is the launch of Garnier for Men. This will be the Garnier proposal for men, and this product, right, was invented and developed in India. And this is the first time in the history of the Group that a big blockbuster – global blockbuster starts from India because it is in India that we find men who have no taboos and who are willing to take care of themselves, so much for the mass-market. Now, quite obviously the biggest potential lies in the mass-market divisions, because there are hundreds, millions of men who really want to take care of their skin, their hair worldwide.

Now, Luxury Products is the smaller part of the iceberg, but we are doing very well in Luxury Products. We have the leading Luxury Products for men. We also have products in the Lancôme and Kiehl's ranges and we will continue. But we will really speed up and make a lot of progress in the Consumer Products division, regarding products for men, and it could become quite an adventure. I must say that there is a recent shift that gives me a lot of ambition for the future.

Now when I compare this growth rate like-for-like to China, also there is a strong 14% in China, it almost pales a little bit against the Latin American market, against Brazil. Is it because Brazil, the strong momentum is particular to this year, particular to this time or unsustainable, or is it that something is holding back growth in China? Number 2, the history of the growth in China has been quite steady, and I have to admit that the history of the growth in Brazil has not been that steady. So maybe I would say that plus 21 or 22 in Brazil on the first 6 months is not something that I can guarantee that we are going to sustain for the next 10 years.

So we are taking advantage of that. I don't think that you can extrapolate more than this. But it's a positive element.

That growth in China, you know growth in China is still good. It's true that there have been many articles saying that doing business in China is maybe not as easy as it was before, and it's probably true. And so definitely this is slowing down for a while, the development of our brands in the country.

from Reuters. This is a question about your investment in sanofi-aventis, and I was wondering if you continue to be happy with that investment. If you have a better timeline on if and when you decide to sell those shares, and what do you think about their bid on Genzyme.

Securities. You talked about the gross margin of gross profit in the first half, there was a strong increase. Do you think it's going to be as stable throughout the entire year, just like you said? These are rather wide ranging topics, I am sorry, but could you please shed some light on them?

I would suggest that Christian explain to you, once again, the reason why we feel that the gross margin won't be quite as good in the second half as it was in the first. It's a mechanical reason which has – is unrelated to the fact to how good we are and how good our performance is. But it's a bit complicated, so Christian is going to explain to you the currency effect, the change in the consolidation of foreign exchanges on the actual rate of gross profit. It's a mathematical equation, has nothing to do with our actual level of performance.

Yes, what we've indicated is not that we were expecting gross margin to be stable, we were expecting gross profit to be slightly higher, which is a bit different from what you're saying. Now, the reason is as follows.

As a company, we only have 32% of our sales in euros, which means by nature we are strongly exposed to the variation of our consolidation currency compared to the other currencies. The vast majority of other currencies, except Venezuela and Argentina, these currencies have improved their position against the euro, which is a very positive for L'Oréal in terms of absolute value in terms of sales, in terms of earnings, but it has a slightly negative impact. It dilutes some of our ratios to a certain extent, and the gross margin ratio is one of them.

And I have given you a figure. In the second half – the gross profit for the second half of 2010, if you take the first – if you take the gross margin of the second half of 2009, 70.7%, and if you calculate it with the current consolidation rates, $1.30 for €1, we get 70 basis points less. So this is the major effect or impact, which means that we have to be very careful when it comes to establishing our gross profit for the entire year. So conversion effect has nothing to do with how expensive the raw materials are, has nothing to do with the actual productivity of our plans, or actually the specialization level of our plans. It is because of the combination of our gross profits outside of the Euro zone.

So much for the technical aspects of Mr. Agon, but deep down we are very happy about what we've achieved in terms of actual gross profit. And as you've mentioned, on purchases we've improved, made a lot of improvements on our purchases. We grouped our buying centers, procurement centers. We now have achieved major gains across all these areas because of optimization. It is true that here and there, there are some raw materials that have gotten very expensive, but we are not worried at all regarding the second half.

Now, as regards the value level, I think that that's what you were referring to, some companies have referred to lower prices. But if I read carefully, these companies are working across several categories which are not ours, they are working in other lines of business. And it's more in the other lines of business that are not competing with ours, that they could see that there were drops in raw materials or prices. In the cosmetics markets we can't say that there is – there was no deflationary change in the market in this first – during this first half. And we had a positive value effect for the first half, which is not quite as high, granted, as it was last year, but it's still 0.7, and it's a value effect which is still positive, satisfactory. The good news is that volumes have picked up in a big way, which is a source of satisfaction.
